isis.stitle: TSI 93-08-03 - Troubleshooting Procedures for On-Off Engine Fan Control Circuits

subjectgroup.subject: Troubleshooting Procedures for On-Off Engine Fan Control Circuits

note.para: This service letter applies only to "normally closed" circuit designs.

lev1.para:
Many engine fan control circuits used on International vehicles incorporate a solid state electronic fan temperature control switch which provides excellent temperature control. International uses a "normally closed" circuit design to assure that failure in this circuit will cause the fan to come on, thus protecting the engine from overheating. Because the switch is electronic, it cannot be continuity tested in the normal manner. In fact, depending on the method used, such testing could cause a good switch to fail.
Attached are step-by-step procedures a technician should use to determine the root cause of a fan control program. The circuit shown is for 9200 through 9400 models. Circuits for other models are similar.

Please note that International recently changed to a 3-wire fan temperature control switch which replaces the former 2-wire switch. The third wire is a ground wire which replaces the case ground of the former 2-wire switch. If replacing a 2-wire switch with a 3-wire switch, connect the eyelet on the new ground wire under a suitable bolt, making sure the surfaces have been cleaned of paint, corrosion, etc. to provide a good ground. The part number of the new 3-wire switch is 1684560C92. It is a 205°F switch and can be used in all former 200°F and 195°F applications.

item.para: Fan engages when engine temperature reaches approximately 205°F and remains on until coolant temperature has been reduced about 10°F.

Fan engages whenever the air conditioning refrigerant pressure exceeds 300 psi and remains on until pressure drops below 210 psi. NOTE: This function is controlled by a mechanical pressure switch installed in the high pressure refrigerant line near the refrigerant compressor.
In moderately hot weather, the fan will cycle on and off about three to four times per minute if the vehicle is idling with the air conditioning ON.
In very hot weather, the fan will run continuously if the air conditioning is ON.
Consult the Troubleshooting Chart ( Table 1) for other conditions.

entry.para: 1. Fan runs all the time with the air conditioning off and the engine coolant temperature below 195°F to 205°F.
Refer to troubleshooting flow chart and repair or replace as necessary.
2. Fan won't cycle when vehicle is idling with the air conditioning ON.
Outside air temperature is too low, there is a low refrigerant charge, or the refrigerant pressure switch is faulty.
Check air conditioning system; replace pressure switch if required.
3. Engine overheating; fan doesn't engage when the engine temperature exceeds 205°F.
Fan drive, air solenoid valve, or related air lines may be faulty.
4. Fan runs all the time with the air conditioning ON.
This is normal in extremely hot weather.
Spraying water on the condenser should temporarily turn off the fan.
Air conditioning system may be overcharged or the condenser is covered with debris.
Pressure switch may have drifted out of calibration. Use service gauge to verify that the fan engages when pressure is approximately 300 psi and turns off when the pressure drops below 210 psi.
5. Fan cycles frequently when vehicle is stationary with the air conditioning ON.
Up to 4 fan cycles per minute is a normal condition in moderately hot weather. Turning off the air conditioning system should cause the cycling to stop.

svcproc.title: SERVICE PROCEDURE
svcproc.para: Refer to Figure 3 and Figure 4 for the following steps.

step1.para: Ignition key off. Disconnect connector 227 at the fan solenoid (part number 1689785C91). Measure the resistance of the solenoid, connecting the ohmmeter "common" lead to the black wire of the solenoid and the "positive" lead to the red wire (with some ohmmeters, measuring backwards will result in a false reading due to the internal solenoid diode). Replace solenoid if coil resistance is greater than 30 ohms or less than 10 ohms. Also measure resistance between each wire and the metal housing of the solenoid. Replace solenoid if resistance to housing is less than 10,000 ohms. If any reading is less than 8 ohms, also replace fan temperature control switch. AVOID USING 12 VOLTS TO TEST THE SOLENOID TO PREVENT POSSIBLE DAMAGE TO THE INTERNAL DIODE. Also check to be sure the red wire of the solenoid is connected to circuit 23D. CONNECTING THE SOLENOID WIRES BACKWARDS WILL CAUSE THE TEMPERATURE SWITCH TO FAIL AND POSSIBLY THE SOLENOID AS WELL.

para.emph: Perform the following steps with the ignition key ON, the engine OFF, and connector 227 disconnected. Engine coolant temperature must be below 190°F.

step1.para: Check for 12 volts in circuit 23 at connector 237. If not present, check circuit 23 for open or short. Check fuse/circuit breaker and check for 12 volts to the fuse/circuit breaker from key switch.
Check for 12 volts in circuit 23C at connector 228. If not present, check circuit 23C for open or short. If circuit 23C is okay, replace fan temperature switch.
Check for 12 volts in circuit 23D at connector 227. If not present, check circuit 23D for open or short. If circuit 23D is okay, replace refrigerant pressure switch.

Vehicles equipped with a 460 HP, 3406 Cat. PEEC III will have a Normally Closed (NC) Intake Temperature Switch located between the refrigerant switch and the fan solenoid (circuit 23D in and 23E out).
This switch opens at 149°F (65°C) and closes at 138°F (57°C).
Measure resistance in circuit 23GB between connector 227 and ground. If greater than 1 ohm, repair ground circuit.
Turn ignition off. Re-connect connector 227. Cycle ignition switch on and off and listen for proper operation of solenoid.
If no electrical problems are found, perform the following:

item.para: Check air lines to fan drive for proper orientation and assure there are no restrictions.
Check fan clutch for proper operation.
